title: Vocabulary
what: Vocabulary means all the words a person knows or uses. It helps us understand and express ideas better.
tutorial: Example: If you know the word 'generous', you can say 'My teacher is generous' instead of 'My teacher gives a lot'.
steps:
1. Learn new words every day.
  2. Use them in a sentence.
  3. Group words by topics like food, school, feelings, etc.
  4. Practice with flashcards or games.

sections.title: Types of Vocabulary
sections.what: Vocabulary can be learned in different ways based on how we use or hear words.
sections.tutorial: There are 4 types: Listening, Speaking, Reading, and Writing vocabulary.
sections.steps:
1. Know the four types of vocabulary.
  2. Identify how you learn best (by reading, hearing, speaking).
  3. Practice each type regularly.

sections.title: Listening Vocabulary
sections.what: Words you understand when you hear them.
sections.tutorial: Example: You hear 'delicious' and know it means something tastes good.
sections.steps:
1. Listen to stories or songs.
  2. Ask what unknown words mean.
  3. Use those words in speaking later.

sections.title: Speaking Vocabulary
sections.tutorial: Example: You say 'I’m excited!' when you feel happy and nervous.
sections.steps:
1. Practice talking with others.
  2. Try to use new words in daily conversation.
  3. Correct yourself if needed.

sections.title: Reading Vocabulary
sections.what: Words you understand when you read them.
sections.tutorial: Example: When you read 'gigantic', you know it means very big.
sections.steps:
1. Read books or articles daily.
  2. Underline new words.
  3. Check the dictionary or context.

sections.title: Writing Vocabulary
sections.tutorial: Example: Writing ‘beautiful’ in a poem or essay.
sections.steps:
1. Write journals or short stories.
  2. Use new words you’ve learned.
  3. Edit to replace simple words with better vocabulary.

sections.title: Ways to Learn Vocabulary
sections.what: There are many fun and effective ways to learn new words.
sections.tutorial: Example: Using flashcards, songs, games, and reading are all great methods.
sections.steps:
1. Choose one or more fun ways to learn.
  2. Be consistent—do it daily.
  3. Track your progress.

sections.title: Using Flashcards
sections.what: Flashcards help you memorize new words fast.
sections.tutorial: Write the word on one side, the meaning on the other.
sections.steps:
1. Prepare index cards or use an app.
  2. Write words and meanings.
  3. Review them every day.

sections.title: Using Word Games
sections.what: Games like Word Search, Scrabble, or crossword puzzles help vocabulary.
sections.tutorial: Play games with friends or online to test your knowledge.
sections.steps:
1. Pick a word game.
  2. Play with new words only.
  3. Check and learn words you didn’t know.

sections.title: Using Context Clues
sections.what: Guess the word's meaning by looking at the sentence around it.
sections.tutorial: Example: 'He is very frugal, never spending too much money.' (Frugal = not spending much)
sections.steps:
1. Read the sentence carefully.
  2. Look for hints in the sentence.
  3. Guess the meaning before checking a dictionary.

sections.title: Using a Personal Dictionary
sections.what: A notebook where you write new words and their meanings.
sections.tutorial: Helps you review and remember better over time.
sections.steps:
1. Buy a small notebook.
  2. Write down new words daily.
  3. Review every week.

sections.title: Word Forms and Usage
sections.what: Words change depending on how they are used.
sections.steps:
1. Learn root words first.
  2. Study how suffixes or prefixes change meaning or form.
  3. Practice using different forms in a sentence.

sections.title: Nouns
sections.what: Words that name people, places, things, or ideas.
sections.steps:
1. List common nouns.
  2. Group by types (person, place, etc.).
  3. Use in sample sentences.

sections.title: Verbs
sections.steps:
1. Make a list of common verbs.
  2. Learn their past and present forms.
  3. Practice in different tenses.

sections.title: Adjectives
sections.steps:
1. List adjectives that describe feelings, colors, sizes.
  2. Use them to describe people or things around you.
  3. Practice making comparisons (tall, taller, tallest).

sections.title: Adverbs
sections.what: Words that describe verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs.
sections.steps:
1. Identify the action word (verb).
  2. Add an adverb to describe how the action is done.
  3. Practice placing adverbs in a sentence.

sections.title: Vocabulary Building Techniques
sections.what: Smart ways to grow your word bank daily.
sections.tutorial: Do a 'Word of the Day', join spelling contests, and read often.
sections.steps:
1. Choose a method to learn new words.
  2. Stick to it every day.
  3. Track new words and use them in your writing or speech.

sections.title: Root Words
sections.what: Base words from which other words are made.
sections.steps:
1. List common roots.
  2. Identify how they combine with other parts.
  3. Guess new words by analyzing root meanings.

sections.title: Affixes (Prefixes and Suffixes)
sections.what: Letters added to the start (prefix) or end (suffix) of a word to change its meaning.
sections.steps:
1. Make two columns for prefixes and suffixes.
  2. List their meanings.
  3. Combine with root words and test meanings.
